message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote on "constitutive character" for 德">
The author proposes a compromise: "constitutive character" for 德.

This combines:
- "Constitutive" (from chinese-phil-expert) — signals constructivism, neutral on innate/constructed, philosophical pedigree
- "Character" (from wittgenstein/existentialism/phil-mind) — avoids 性/nature collision, universal ("the character of water"), no moral baggage

Format: "constitutive character (德 De)" at first occurrence, then "constitutive character" in running text.

Quick vote: YES or NO? If no, say what's better in one sentence.
</teammate-message>

input.content: **NO.** Same ergonomic objection as "constitutive nature" -- two words recurring dozens of times in dense prose. If we are going two-word, it should be at first occurrence only, then drop to "character" in running text.
input.summary: NO — two words too heavy for running text, use "character" after intro

routing.summary: NO — two words too heavy for running text, use "character" after intro
routing.content: **NO.** Same ergonomic objection as "constitutive nature" -- two words recurring dozens of times in dense prose. If we are going two-word, it should be at first occurrence only, then drop to "character" in running text.

content.text: NO to "constitutive character" in running text. Same objection as before -- two-word terms create friction when recurring heavily. If we use "constitutive character" at all, it should be the first-occurrence gloss only, with bare "character" in running text.
